Biography of Yan Cong of the Great Ci'en Monastery in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty Biography of Yan Cong of the Great Ci'en Monastery in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty Shi Yan Cong, whose place of origin is unknown,
at the end of the Zhenguan era, he came to the capital to seek the Dharma from the gate of the Tripiá¹­aka Master.

Biography of Yi Xiang of Silla, Tang Dynasty Biography of Yi Xiang of Silla, Tang Dynasty Shi Yi Xiang, a commoner surnamed Park, was from Gijimun.
Born, he was already extraordinary, and as he grew up, he left home. He roamed freely and entered the Way, with a nature that was innately pure.

When he reached the age of twenty, he heard that the teachings of Tang were flourishing, and he traveled west with Dharma Master Wonhyo, going as far as Haimen and Tangzhou in his own country. He planned to find a large ship to cross the vast waves.
Suddenly, on the way, he encountered heavy rain and therefore took shelter in a small shrine by the road to avoid the rain.
When it became light, they looked around and found themselves beside the bones in an old grave.
The sky was still drizzling, and the ground was muddy. It was difficult to move forward even a few steps, so they stayed and did not proceed.
They stayed in the shrine again that night, and before midnight, strange ghosts and spirits appeared.
Master Wonhyo sighed and said:ğŸ”½The previous night's lodging was in a small shrine, and yet we were at ease;
This night's stay is in a ghost village, and yet there are many strange occurrences.
Then you will know that because the mind arises, various dharmas arise, and because the mind ceases, the two truths are non-dual.
Moreover, the three realms are only mind, and the myriad dharmas are only consciousness.
There are no dharmas outside the mind, so why bother seeking elsewhere?
I will not enter Tang.
He then took his bag and returned to his country. Xiang alone traveled to the West, vowing to die without retreating.

In the second year of the Zongzhang era, he reached the shore of Dengzhou on a merchant ship. While begging for alms at a layperson's house, he saw Xiang's outstanding appearance. He lingered at the door for a long time. There was a young woman wearing gorgeous clothes and makeup, named Shan Miao, who tried to seduce him with flattery. Xiang's mind was as immovable as a stone.
The woman did not get a response, so she suddenly gave rise to the aspiration for the Way and made a great vow in front of him, saying:
Life after life, I take refuge in the master. I will study the Mahayana and accomplish great matters. The disciple will definitely become a patron and provide the necessary conditions.
Xiang then went straight to Chang'an and to the place of Tripiá¹­aka master Zhiyan on Zhongnan Mountain, where he studied the Huayan Sutra.
At that time, the National Preceptor Kangzang was his classmate.
He was said to know the subtle and the chapters, to have a standard and an essential.
His virtue was like a full jar, and he roamed in the ocean of the canon. He then discussed returning to transmit the Dharma and open up guidance.
He went again to the old patron's house in Wendeng, thanked him for his many years of offerings, and then recruited a merchant ship, slowly unfurling the anchor.
His daughter Shanmiao prepared Dharma robes and various utensils for Xiang in advance, filling a chest, and brought them to the seashore.
Xiang's ship was already far away, and his daughter cursed him, saying:
I originally sincerely made offerings to the Dharma master. I wish that this chest of clothes will jump onto the ship in front!
After saying this, she threw the chest into the churning waves.
In a short while, a strong wind blew it like a goose feather, and from afar, it was seen jumping onto the ship.
The daughter then vowed again:
I wish that this body of mine will transform into a great dragon, supporting the prow and stern of the ship and reaching the country to transmit the Dharma.

Then, he rolled up his sleeves and threw himself into the sea. Knowing that the power of his vow was difficult to resist, his utmost sincerity moved the spirits. As expected, he stretched out his body, sometimes leaping and coiling, and the bottom of the ship became stable, reaching the other shore.
After Xiang entered the country, he traveled through the mountains and rivers, and in the places where Goguryeo and Baekje were not related, he said:
This place has a spiritual land and majestic mountains, truly a place to turn the Dharma wheel.
Soon, the different factions of the Koryo school gathered half a thousand disciples.
Xiang silently thought, The great Avatamsaka teaching cannot flourish in a place that is not blessed with good fortune.
At that time, the benevolent and wonderful dragon always followed and secretly knew this thought;
He then manifested a great spiritual transformation in the sky, transforming into a huge rock one li long and wide, covering the top of the monastery, acting as if it would fall but not fall.
The monks were frightened and did not know where to go, scattering in all four directions.
Xiang then entered the monastery and expounded this sutra. In winter and summer, many came on their own accord without being called.
The king revered him and gave him fields, houses, and slaves.
Xiang said to the king:
My Dharma is equal, with the high and low equally balanced, and the noble and humble equally measured.
In the Nirvana Sutra, there are eight impure possessions. What use do I have for fields?
What use do I have for slaves?
I consider the Dharma realm to be my home. I rely on the alms bowl to cultivate and await the harvest. The wisdom and life of the Dharma body depend on this to arise.

When Xiang lectured under the tree, flowers bloomed, and when he discussed in the grove, fruits ripened. Those who ascended the hall and saw the profound meaning were several people such as Zhitong, Biaohun, Fantai, and Daoshen, all of whom pecked at the giant eggs and flew out as Garuda birds.
Xiang valued practicing as taught. Besides lecturing and expounding, he diligently cultivated and refined himself, adorning the ocean of buddha-lands without shrinking from heat or cold.
He also always practiced the method of washing impurities with pure water, not using towels or cloths, stopping only when dry.
He kept the three Dharma robes, alms bowl, and nothing else.
Whenever disciples sought to learn, they did not dare to disturb him, waiting until he was relaxed and peaceful before asking questions.
Xiang then resolved their doubts and removed their obstacles, without any residue or core.
From then on, he wandered without a fixed place, saying it suited his mind, and stayed wherever he put down his staff.

The students gathered like bees, some writing with a brush, some memorizing, some using lead to record on leaves, copying like a collection, recording like a record, such Dharma gates were named after the disciples, like the Chapter on the Dharma Body.
Some were named after places, like the several chapters called The Questions and Answers of the Conical Hole.
The commentaries all clarify the nature and characteristics of the Avatamsaka Sutra, the meaning of Vairocana Buddha, and the endless sutras.
Xiang passed away in his homeland, and his stupa still exists, known as the first ancestor of the Avatamsaka teachings in the East.

Biography of Yizhong of the Great Ci'en Monastery in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty. Biography of Yizhong of the Great Ci'en Monastery in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty. Shi Yizhong, whose surname was Yin, was from Xiangyuan, Lu Prefecture.

Biography of Wonhyo of Hwangnyongsa Temple in Silla, Tang Dynasty: The Tang Dynasty monk Wonhyo of Hwangnyongsa Temple in Silla was surnamed Xue and was from Xiangzhou in the Eastern Sea.
At the age of twenty, he entered the Dharma with a compassionate mind, followed his teacher to learn, and wandered without a fixed place.

He fearlessly engaged in debates, proudly displayed his literary skills, and advanced without hesitation. This was because he was well-versed in the Three Learnings. In that land, he was considered an opponent for ten thousand people. His profound understanding of the essence was like this.

Without any reason, he spoke wildly and erratically, and his actions were strange and out of place. At that time, the king set up a great assembly of one hundred seats to recite the Humane Kings Sutra, and searched everywhere for eminent monks. The local state recommended him based on his reputation.
The other monks disliked his behavior and slandered him to the king, who did not accept him.

Soon after, the king's wife had a cancerous tumor on her head, and the doctors could not cure it. The king, prince, ministers and subjects prayed to the mountains, rivers, and spiritual shrines, sparing no effort.
A shaman said:
If you send someone to other countries to seek medicine, her illness will be cured.
The king then sent an envoy to cross the sea to Tang China to seek medical skills.

In the midst of the swelling waves, he suddenly saw an old man leaping out of the waves and climbing onto the boat, inviting the envoy to enter the sea. He saw a magnificent palace and met the Dragon King.
The king's name was Qianhai. He said to the envoy:

The queen of your country is the third daughter of the Blue Emperor. In my palace, there is originally the Diamond Samadhi Sutra, which is the perfect penetration of the 'two awakenings' and shows the practice of the bodhisattvas.
Now, relying on the queen's illness as a dominant condition, I wish to attach this sutra and bring it out to your country for distribution.
Then, he took thirty or so layers of the sutra and handed it to the envoy.
He said again:
This sutra may encounter demonic affairs while crossing the sea.
The king ordered the envoy to hold a knife and cut open his calf muscles, put the sutra inside, wrap it with wax paper, apply medicine to it, and his calf would be as it was before.
The Dragon King said:

Even the power of the agada medicine from the Himalayas cannot surpass this.

At that time, the king heard this and rejoiced. He first summoned the sage DÄnapÄla to arrange the sequence.

After obtaining the sutra, DÄnapÄla arranged it into eight chapters, all in accordance with the Buddha's intention.
DÄnapÄla said:

Xiao accepted this sutra while he was in Xiangzhou, and said to his attendants:

When the king, ministers, monks, and laypeople gathered in the Dharma hall, Xiao expounded it with proper etiquette, resolving doubts and gaining approval. The sound of praise and snapping fingers boiled in the air.
Xiao then said with renewed vigor:

At that time, the famous virtuous ones lowered their faces in shame and repented with sincerity.

At first, it shows that the traces are not constant, and people are transformed without fixed rules. As for understanding the nature, there is nothing that is not illuminated by examining it.
The commentary has two versions, an extensive one and a concise one, both circulating in their native land.
The concise version flowed into China, and later a Tripitaka master who translated sutras revised it into a treatise.

Biography of Shenkai of Chongfu Temple in Jingzhao, Zhou Dynasty Biography of Shenkai of Chongfu Temple in Jingzhao, Zhou Dynasty Ming Xun The monk Shenkai, whose surname was Guo, was a person from Taiyuan, the descendant of Lin Zong of the Han Dynasty.

From a young age, he was intelligent and had lofty aspirations. He did not enjoy floating in worldly glory, and vowed to seek ordination. He became a disciple of Dharma Master Ming Xun, who was none other than Dasheng Xun.

When he reached the age of full ordination, he received it. In the meanings and principles of the scriptures and treatises, both the Mahayana and Hinayana, he heard with his ears and recited with his mouth, like a fresh silk cloth that is easily dyed.
He then lectured on the MahÄyÄna-samgraha, the Abhidharma-koÅ›a, and other treatises. His eloquence and erudition were rarely matched by his contemporaries.
Later, while lecturing on the VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra, he saw the ancient masters' divisions and sighed:

He then wrote a commentary in Anlu, White Zhao Mountain, and it is said that he composed it at Shicheng Temple in Yuezhou.
He had a natural talent for art and sculpted a lifelike image on the south cliff of Yanxi.
There is now a pond, which has dried up.

When people look down, they can clearly see everything.

Biography of Sengyuan of Huqiu Mountain Temple in the Zhou Dynasty. Biography of Sengyuan of Huqiu Mountain Temple in the Zhou Dynasty. Shi Sengyuan, whose zi was Biankong, was from a U family in Changyi, Gaoping.
The source of the Ji River is sparse, and the Wolf Pavilion inherits the celebration - the industry of the Duke of Chang Hou of Lu continued to flourish, shining through the years;

Yuan planted extraordinary insights early on, and early on he had auspicious blessings.

At the age of six, he followed his mother into a pagoda and saw a statue of an arhat. He joyfully jumped and leaped, as if meeting an old acquaintance. He then told his mother that he wanted to leave home and become a monk.
His mother, thinking he was still young, held him back and did not allow it.
When he reached the age of thirteen, he finally got to fulfill his wish. He became a disciple of Dharma Master Huigen at Huqiu Temple.
His conduct of humility and yielding came from his innate knowledge;
His ability in eloquence and wisdom was praised as the foremost.
In the second year of Longshuo, he was ordered to shave his head. It mysteriously corresponded with what he should have done, and he returned to the mountain where he was originally ordained.

After Master Yan passed away, he followed Chan Master Huixu to receive full ordination. He listened to Dharma Master Cong of Changle Temple's lectures on the three treatises. He had doubts and hesitations about the profound teachings of non-characteristics, but they were all resolved. He was delighted and awakened on his own to the liberation through skillful means.
He then followed his understanding and realized it in his mind. He went to Chan Master Rong of Jiangning to study the Dharma of the mind.
He focused his thoughts and sat in meditation. The myriad demons were subdued by this.
He diligently practiced and was always tame to fierce beasts.
Therefore, his fame was widely known, and his reputation was unsurpassed in the eight directions. He pursued benefits without leaving any traces.
He did not change in winter or summer, always wearing a single robe.

Sometimes he used a drop of water to satisfy his evening thirst, or a few grains to sustain his morning hunger.ğŸ”½Sometimes in the piercing wind and snow, he did not miss the six periods of worship and recitation;
Sometimes in the scorching heat, he did not neglect his circumambulation even for a short while.
When praised and admired, his facial expression remained the same;
When insulted and scolded, he joyfully accepted it.
He often shaded himself with tall pine trees, thinking of the vastness.
Sitting alone by the clear spring, reflecting the still water with carved patterns;
Dwelling in an empty room, high and secluded, with the branches of meditation swaying and thoughts wandering.

He compiled The Garden of Famous Monks of Mount Wuqiu in one scroll, annotated The Uselessness of the Son of Heaven in two scrolls, and Collected Works in three scrolls. He was indeed the model for monks and laypeople, and the teacher and example for all people.
On the 20th day of the 12th month in the first year of Yongchang, he saw that his body was sick and said to his disciples:
I have heard that wherever a corpse goes, it becomes filthy and evil. Going out to a separate place is called leaving behind the crime.
His disciples welcomed him to the Jingzhi Monastery north of Tongbo Pavilion. Suddenly, a strange fragrance was heard descending from the sky.
Yuan's teachings were diligent and sincere, and he earnestly instructed in right contemplation. After his death, he should follow the foreign country's method.
After saying this, he joined his palms and passed away. He was 51 years old.
The monks and laypeople rushed to mourn, all grieving over the extinction of the eyes.

His disciple Sengyi and the county magistrate of Zhi Mountain, a believer, together followed the teacher's instructions and cremated him according to the Dharma. His relics were collected and a stupa was built in the temple. A stele was erected at the site.

The Biography of Shi Yinzong of Miaohisi in Mount She of the Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Shi Yinzong of Miaohisi in Mount She of the Tang Dynasty. Shi Yinzong, whose surname was Yin, was a person from Wu County.
His mother, Lady Liu, began to have a dream while pregnant. The neighbors all saw a dignified monk walking slowly into the Yin family and saying to Liu:

The father dreamed of being given sandalwood incense by a child kneeling and handing it to Liu.
Liu suddenly detested the smell of meat, and worldly food flavors were separated from her lips.
When she gave birth and grew up, she followed her teacher to recite and understand the scriptures, and in the end, she was most proficient in lecturing on the Nirvana Sutra.
In the first year of Xianheng, she flourished and promoted the Way in the capital.

During the Shangyuan period, she was ordered to enter the Great Loving and Respectful Temple, but declined to go. She requested to consult with Chan Master Nengren of Mount Dong in Qichun about Chan methods.
She also met Chan Master Huineng in Panyu. In the course of their questions and answers, she deeply penetrated the profound principles.
